claims.claim: Intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine induces a type I interferon-rich inflammatory state in tumours.

evidence.quote: The paper investigates whether intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine can create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 therapy.
Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.
| Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors |

claims.caveat: The report summarizes a mechanistic chain, but also notes that some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings (L53).

claims.claim: mRNA vaccination is associated with increased antigen processing/presentation and a broader MHC-I peptide repertoire in tumours.

evidence.quote: Interferon-associated antigen processing and presentation pathways increase.
A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.
| Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6% | Strong expansion of MHC-I-presented landscape |

claims.caveat: Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors, and some mechanistic readouts varied across model systems (L52-L53).

claims.claim: In murine tumour models, combining intratumoral mRNA vaccination with anti-PD-L1 is described as improving tumour control and immune infiltration relative to baseline contexts.

evidence.quote: - Preclinical arm: multiple murine tumor models with intratumoral mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1 combinations.
Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.
| Intratumoral CD8+ T-cell density fold-change | 1.8x | 1.0x | Increased immune infiltration with combination therapy |

claims.caveat: The report notes that vaccine-only and ICI-only conditions had limited or non-durable effects in some settings (L36-L37), and mouse model results may not translate directly to human tumours (L52).

claims.claim: In a retrospective metastatic patient cohort receiving ICI therapy, prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status was associated with improved survival.

evidence.quote: - Translational arm: a retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, compared by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.
| Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment |
Human retrospective metastatic cohort: 130 patients total.

claims.caveat: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized with likely residual confounding, and vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients (L49-L50).

claims.claim: The sensitization effect depends on mRNA and type I interferon signaling, based on perturbation and control conditions described.

evidence.quote: - Mechanistic probes: immunopeptidomics, transcriptomics, and perturbation controls (including IFNAR1 blockade and non-mRNA particle controls).
- Lipid particle controls lacking mRNA did not reproduce the sensitization effect.
- Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.

claims.caveat: The report frames these as controls/perturbations within preclinical settings; the extent to which the same dependency governs human outcomes is not established and mouse-to-human mapping is uncertain (L52).
